dialogues.text: Nigger, shut up so we can hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is up. Fool be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is just playing possum. He's waiting for an  opening.  The waiters are acting as if they are at ringside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A left jab to the jaw and a right cross, scored  by Louis and Conn is hurt, as Louis rips a  right to the jaw. Conn is staggering, but he  won't go down. Conn bops a left hook, he's  reeling around the ring. Louis hooks a left and  a right to the jaw and Conn is down.  The waiters are going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's taking the count, four, five, six, seven,  he's on his back, eight, nine, he's getting up,  no! The referee says it's over. The bout has  stopped. The waiters are all jumping up and down when the galley d COOPER, the white man in charge of the kitchen, pops his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a moment's notice Tully and the others have resumed th servient roles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a lot of hungry customers out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Mr. Cooper, soup done finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Mr. Cooper and don't you forget it.  Mr. Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winner and still champion, Joe Louis, but  what a fight Billy Conn gave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Malcolm hefts his sandwich basket and a large containe down the aisle, hawking as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your good haaaam and cheeeeese sandwiches.  I got coffee, I got cake and I got ice cream  too. Right chere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, boy. Gimme a cheese on white and coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm's mood is exuberant: the fight is still in his ea the delivery with a flourish and a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Best in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mighty pleased with yourself, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I aims to please.

dialogues.text: 45A        INSERT - FANTASY PROJECTION. Malcolm picks up pushes it in Blades' face.

dialogues.text: And takes a satisfying bite out of his thin sandwich.

dialogues.text: As the Clipper surfaces in Harlem, pulls up to the 125th station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, out of uniform and dressed in his zoot suit, com the Park Avenue station in Harlem. He is hit with the sig Everything delights him: the noise, the lights, the women the signs, the windows, the crowds, the laughter, the mus

dialogues.text: A CROWD OF PEOPLE run by Malcolm yelling and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brown Bomber, The Brown Bomber, Joe Louis,  the heavyweight champion of the world. Joe got  the belt back. Lawd have mercy. Great day in  the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All traffic has stopped, there is a huge spontaneous cele on. Black folks are everywhere, it seems as if all of Har the streets. The citizens of Harlem are hugging, kissing, dancing, folks are hanging from street lamps, yelling out windows, holding up hand-made JOE LOUIS banners, everyone reason to be joyous. The heavyweight champion of the worl MAN -- JOE LOUIS, THE BROWN BOMBER, he has regained his c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm quickly looks at his watch, he's running late for he fights his way through the crowd like a salmon going u CAMERA CRANES up to see him eventually get lost in a sea HUMANITY "cutting loose."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, newly conked and sharp as a tack (zoot suit, tro like a knife's edge, orange knob-toed shoes) walks toward Small's Paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is crowded with PEOPLE, KIDS and HUSTLERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, daddy, what's your hurry? Lemme show  you somepin brand new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, hundred-dollar ring -- diamond; and a  ninety dollar watch. Take the both of them for  a quarter; twenty-five bucks. Malcolm waves; he's not having any. Goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before entering, Malcolm sharps himself a bit, picking of cocking his hat. And enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is crowded, both at the bar and at the tab The immediate impression is of subdued well-being, of dec affluence. This is the world Malcolm wants into. He digs in its details.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: A big man, FOX, accidentally bumps into Malcolm almost kn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, country boy, you shouldn't have been in  my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone becomes quiet in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you gonna do? Go run home to your  Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm grabs a bottle off the bar counter and with light brings it crashing down on Fox's head. As he lays on the head bleeding, Malcolm kicks him in the stomach _two time the fight is over and people pull him off of Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever again in life step on my Florsheims  again, and never talk-bout my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double's on that gentleman. Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elderly man nods. He is big, he is very black. The sa Malcolm's father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his glass, toasts Archie and downs it. Then lea bar, asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender would not normally answer this, but Malcolm the moment, so the bartender speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm nods, then looks over again at Archie -- in appre Archie wiggles a finger for him to come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. We ain't fixing to eat you. You look  brand new in town. Pretty handy with a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm sits. There are no introductions. He just nods at CADILLAC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red, and I ain't no punk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not be. Cause if a cat toe you down  in this town, you better stand up or make  tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fact. What you do, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps me out of the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they want your ass, won't nothing keep you  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this boy... I ain't fighting their war. I  got my own. Right chere. Heard tell you're a  good man to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy and Cadillac are watching a little skeptically. Arc flattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sombitch and I ain't never been to Beantown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then seeing Sammy and Cadillac's dubious visages, Archie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't bullshitting me, is you, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My papa taught me one thing: don't never  bullshit a West Indian bullshit artist. Archie laughs. Even Sammy smiles. Cadillac still holds hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my mama. She's from Grenada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only where'd you get them goddam vines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, got to do something about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You putting a hurtin' on my vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy covers his eyes. Malcolm plays off the insults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can I get a hold of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU can't. I'll get a hold of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme write it down for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't never write nothing down. File it up  here, like I do. (touching his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause if they can't find no paper they ain't  got no proof. Ya dig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, look me in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you just now con me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I want in. And it don't take a lot to  know you there, daddy. Archie and Sammy laugh at his directness. Cadillac smiles pushes back his chair, about to get up.  ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got me a little run to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has suddenly been excluded and he wants desperate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I run with you, Mr. Archie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie eyes him, weighing him seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your heart and I like your style. You  might just do, Little. Lessen you got to git  back to that train job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I done told the man what he could do with his  train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three established hustlers smile at the newcomer in t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, baby. We going shopping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is looking at himself in a mirror in Archie's roo the full outfit now, together with a new white on white s Sulka tie. Looks great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the middle button, baby. Just the middle  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm buttons the jacket and turns around, demonstratin inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looking good, Little. Real clean. Clean as  the Board of Health. But you missing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frisk me, baby. Give me a real pat down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm doesn't understand, but he senses something -- an excited. Archie has walked over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm frisks him carefully: pats his sides, his pockets arms, his legs. Archie is clean to the touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm still carrying. He smacks the small of his back. Then, reaching under his takes a revolver out from the middle of his back. And han Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the deadly instrument, fascinated by it, hefting its power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yours, baby. Put it on. Malcolm slips it carefully into the small of his back, be trouser belt. His first gun: the feeling shines in his ey become a black man. ARCHIE (contd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, baby. Now you outfitted. You ready to  tackle the street?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. VARIOUS LOCATIONS
dialogues.text: A FIVE DOLLAR BILL. CAMERA GOES IN for the last three dig 64A        STOCK MARKET BOARD at the end of a day's tradi three numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us turn to the Gospel according to St.  John. Chapter 3, Verse  83.

dialogues.text: Malcolm scribbles the number onto a piece of paper.

dialogues.text: Malcolm's hand writes out the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads "New York to Chicago." PAN DOWN TO SHOW "Train a
Archie with Malcolm as the latter writes down "1, 0, 5."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you less paper, less trouble.  MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep all my numbers in my head. I've never  written any down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it in my dream. 5, 5, 5. And last week my  sister had a dream and she hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it from Ching Chow. It got to be 2, 5, 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE ARE TIGHT ON Malcolm's intense face, he is pulling on We hear BOGART blasting his way out of a police blockade. A phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is music playing. Wordlessly, Archie sprinkles a fe fine crystal onto a round shaving mirror. He slides it ac to Malcolm and hands him a short straw. Sophia sits next she and Archie are already high. Malcolm leans over the m the straw in his nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the mirror (something satanic about him) -- as he snif well into his nose. A beat as he leans back waiting for the drug to take hold looks into dressing mirror. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nnnnnnn! Malcolm with gun in hand does his Bogart gangster imitati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nuthin' in the world to give you that  real deep cool. Like girl. You there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm there, daddy. Wheww. I'm cool enough to  kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to laugh.  BACK TO REAL TIME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any money. Before Sophia can answer he grabs her pocketbook, dumping contents on the floor but the dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, I was gonna give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, bitch you move too slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you got a big ugly mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I'm putting my money where my ugly  mouth is. I'm putting you back in the numbers  right now. (to Sophia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia is not sure of this, or anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, put me down for a combination. Combinate  me, daddy: 8, 2, 1. You got me? 8, 1, 2; 1, 8,  2...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With each number he throws a bill at Archie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1, 2, 8; 2, 8, 1.  I git 'em all? ARCHIE  (angrily taking the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm slides his tongue down Sophia's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A miserable night, raining and cold. Malcolm turns into t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaking off the rain as Malcolm walks through. He is now figure to the bar's DENIZENS. He is met with ad lib cries Little," "Have a taste," from the men; and from the women sugar," "Where you been?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm acknowledges the greetings, strolls down in the b immediately clear that a subtle change has come over him. longer the neophyte but a well-groomed, smooth, fully pol

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Malcolm sits into the booth and motions for the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine copper tan waitress comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said we were going to the movies  last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And like a fool I believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your job, Get me a bourbon on the rocks and  a pack of Lucky's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. He leans his head back against the booth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm turns his head sharply at the sound of the voice. familiar, a sound from the seemingly distant past. He loo bar and sees the women who asked the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Laura, but not the Laura we last saw. She is still y vulnerable, but she is bolder, more self-assured, more vi She is unaware of Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE FAVORING DANIEL. He is a young, cocky, nervous, gin colored boy who comes over to her quickly. He goes to the bar and quickly grabs Laura's neck and kisses her hungril

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, gorgeous, how you been? Waiting long?  Lemme see you. Wow! It's obvious he's a junkie. And in need of a fix. QUICK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey places his drink and cigarettes before him. He's wa it all in immediately. Laura is clearly crazy about Danie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks, then belts down his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel motions to her pocketbook and she takes out a five He grabs it, and bolts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind your own goddamn business ... She comes in  a lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she got eyes, she do.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Walking toward the door, looking for Daniel. She leaves t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. But the way things going, that boy  gonna turn her out any day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm smacks the table in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: GLASS
dialogues.text: Malcolm's glass on the table is trembling.  MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, bitch. He raises his arm to hit her and it is held back before i mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie is standing above him. Malcolm nods, and Archie le standing next to him is Sophia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, he didn't mean it. Archie wiggles his fingers and Honey goes, but not before daggers at Malcolm and Sophia. Archie sits down, takes ou a good beat there is a coolness between them. Then Malcol and lights Archie's cigar. Sophia stares at her man, he t for her to sit down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. You got it. Who's beating on you, Red?  You looking a little up tight. The father-son thing is back, but Malcolm will never agai student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me six big ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was you that high? Old man, I threw the slats at you. I said to combinate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie doesn't even look at Sophia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, what else she gonna say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then skip it, man. But you slipping, baby. You  done slipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie is controlling himself. Everyone in Small's is all falling out between Malcolm and Archie -- their reps are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. Archie looks at Sammy. Sammy is neutral. Archie di pockets, comes up with a roll. He peels off six $100 bill them on the table in front of himself, as he gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sit down, man. What you tasting? I'm buying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't drinking hot piss with you. Come on, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-two years he didn't never forget no  number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to be a first time, daddy-o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gonna, check the collector he turn into. His  rep is on the line, boy, and so's yours. If you  lying, one of you is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, sweetlips, I got us some g-i-r-l,  girl. Let's you and me fly.

dialogues.text: The well-known 52nd Street nightspot features Billie Holi stand-up cutout of her is outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a plush nightclub, with a mixed black and white A of the hustlers from Small's are in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Lady Day starts into "YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT LOVE IS."

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Malcolm and Sophia high as a kite and on the town.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIE
dialogues.text: He makes his way toward Malcolm's table. There is murder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You _took_ me, you bastard, and now I'm taking  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me or you, ain't it, Pops?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM'S P0V
dialogues.text: Sammy at the nearby bar: his hand in his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand is also in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every cat's watching, ain't they? It's a  toe-down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it is. Walk on out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie backs away from the table, his gun on Malcolm.  ANGLE. As Sammy moves a step toward Malcolm, Malcolm rise

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, I got to let this old man win. Keep the  faith, and tell Billie I'll see her later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - Sammy and Archie are walking behind Malcolm, when waitress into their path with drinks flying everywhere, M away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He races into the men's room. ANGLE. Archie and Sammy run after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an open window. Archie is leaning out, looking b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny alleyway. No one is visible. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't push it. You way ahead. You back on top.  That boy loves you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave it to you, Archie. He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm comes running out of an alleyway and onto the str to catch his breath, to regain his composure. He is shook frustrated, but mostly saddened. He then runs down the bl CLOSEUP.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Earl is sitting up in bed, he wakes his sleeping wife Lou her is a baby in a crib, another child. Malcolm sleeps be her.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Outside the house are 5 members of THE BLACK LEGION. They in the style of the KKK, but in black sheets rather than gasoline cans being passed around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody out there. Wake the children.  Earl starts to put on his overalls and reaches for his gu on a nearby chair when an explosion of flames greets the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody out. OUT! OUT! Get the kids.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Flames roar through the room and the Little kids are hyst rushes in and pushes them past the fire, she has infant i in a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire house is in flames. The Little family stands i just out of harm's way.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK LEGION
dialogues.text: They sit on their horses watching the results of their wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, good thing we're good Christians. Nigger,  it's time for you to leave this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here is 'pose to be a free country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev, we warned you 'bout that Garvey preaching,  stirring up the good nigras here. Boy, next  time you're a dead nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't a boy. I'm a man, and a real man don't  hide behind no bedsheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl takes his pistol out from behind his back and fires heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take these here bullets for dem sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bullets send the Black Legion flying into the gloriou moonlit night.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: The burning house collapses behind the Little family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl, I know you a better shot than that. You  shoulda killed 'em all, shot 'em dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to scare 'em, they won't be  bothering us no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Malcolm stares at his father while the house still him, no doubt drawing on the great courage displayed by h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't be here no time soon. I'm a MAN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining cats and dogs and it's foggy. We hear a big grunt and Earl Little falls across the trolley tracks, th running away is heard in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EARL ON TRACKS
dialogues.text: He has been beaten to a bloody pulp.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: He opens his one good eye.

dialogues.speaker: STREETCAR MOTORMAN
dialogues.text: He sees something ahead in the fog and rain.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMAN
dialogues.text: Winces and then makes the Sign of the Cross.

dialogues.speaker: LONG SHOT OF PASSENGERS
dialogues.text: Jumping out of the streetcar to attend to Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doctor, get him a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's skull, on one side was crushed in,  and then laid across some tracks, for a  streetcar to run him over. His body was cut  almost in half. My father, Earl Little lived  two and a half hours in that condition. Negroes  were stronger than they are now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shorty is driving with Sophia in the front seat. Malcolm back. They are in the country -- outside New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I'm glad we got you out of there. With  West Indian Archie on your ass, your name on  the wire -- Boston the best goddam place in the  world for you -- things are too hot and it's  not even summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has withdrawn within himself. He takes out a pack and sniffs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it easy. I got a place fixed up on  Harvard Square. How's that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cool it and lay dead for a while, Homeboy.  And don't worry none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drug takes hold. Malcolm is out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stake you, baby. I got my band. I'm  blowing great sax. Hell, you ain't even heard  us--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Sophia keep talking it up, trying to bolster Malco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoned, his nose running, Malcolm stares out of the windo receding landscape. FREEZE FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like every hustler I was trapped. Cats that  hung together trying to find a little security,  to find an answer -- found nothing. Cats that  might have probed space or cured cancer --  (Hell, Archie might have been a mathematical  genius) -- all victims of whitey's social order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music of a dance combo heard in BG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three things I was always scared of: a job, a  bust and jail. I realized then I wasn't afraid  of anything. I didn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shorty, Sophia and PEG face Malcolm -- stoned in a chair. Sophia's kid sister and Shorty's date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to eat somethin', Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah and get a slave, too, huh, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, the name musicians ain't got shit. How you  gonna have something? I need a stake, a bundle,  a grand. My woman can't afford it; my homey  ain't got it. How about you baby? What you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Red, she's just a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus ain't got nothin' to do with this.  Shorty eyes him with amazement. The degree of Malcolm's d surprises even him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise you, baby? Well, that's the way it is.  What kind of scratch you got on you? Turn out.  Let me have it. All of you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glances exchanged among Shorty, Sophia and Peg. Shorty re pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm with Sophia, Shorty and Peg around him. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gone rob this town blind. Anybody want out  say so.  Nobody answers; they'll go with Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I got the stake and I got a fence. I need  a driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY is with them. He is a good-looking, very-light skinn tough as they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm half wop, half nigger and ain't afraid of  no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in the process of appraising each other, seeing the bigger penis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy does catering. Rich joints on Beacon Hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This rich ofay, like he's 60. I give him  a bath on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peg and Sophia are listening, a little horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I put him to bed and pour talcum powder on  him like a baby. He gets his jollies off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? The man got silver, china, rugs--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might be, shit. Man, I know this town. I got my  own fences. Who the hell are you? Who put you  in charge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to be the head man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, baby. Let's flip for it. Flip this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his gun, a .38 revolver. He dumps the shells then reinserts one shell and twirls the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the revolver to his own head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm squeezes the trigger. It clicks. Now he twirls th and hands the gun to Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your flip, baby. Rudy is staring at him; so are they all. Malcolm puts the temple again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red, for God's sake--  He pulls the trigger a second time. Click. Now he twirls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand it.  Malcolm puts the gun to Rudy's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn, Rudy. You want me to flip for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, no. Okay, okay. You got it, you  got it! You're the boss.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't never try to cross someone who ain't  afraid to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nodding accord from Rudy and Shorty. Sophia can hardly st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. We'll start with Old Talcum Powder.  You draw the house, where everything is. You  and Peg go out and buy them tools like I told  you. We hit tonight on account of in the  daytime some of us got that high visibility.  Ya dig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy is at a table drawing a diagram; the girls have left Malcolm alone at a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do, Homey, palm it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He breaks open the gun -- the bullet is in the next slot MALCOLM (contd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palmed it right in the goddam chamber.  SHORTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Homey, you are nuts.  Malcolm starts laughing: a silent, hysterical laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The robbery, IN QUICK CUTS:  --A door lock is picked by Sophia. 96A        --Pencil flashlight passes an upstairs window. 96B        --Rudy in the car. 96C        --Silver removed from a drawer by Shorty.  96D        --Peg walking down the street, as lookout.  96E        --Malcolm takes off his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96F        --The sleeping OLD MAN, OLD TALCUM POWDER, as wallet from within inches of his pillow. Then, more boldl the man's hand and removes a ring from one of his fingers watching with bated breath, he's about to have a heart at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Boston matron, MRS. CRAWFORD, is showing the girls her U.S. silver. In a fine New England home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing a survey for the Athenaeum Society  -- We wondered if you'd permit us to include  your collection in the catalog of Great New  England Antiques--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now these are my prizes. My Paul Revere silver  coffee service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia is casing the room carefully as the matron continu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my husband's collection of scrimshaw should  be included.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners face the bench: Peg, Sophia, Shorty, Rudy a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The average first offender gets two years for  burglary. We were all first offenders. That's  what Sophia and Peg drew--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years in the Women's Reformatory at  Framingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But our crime wasn't burglary. It was balling  white girls. They gave us the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burglary, count one -- 8 to 10 years; count two,  8 to 10 years; count three, 8 to 10 years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues giving them 8 to 10 years, behind Malcolm's VOICE OF MALCOLM X

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shorty thought he hit us with 114 years till I  explained what concurrently meant. It meant a  minimum sentence of 10 years hard labor at the  Charlestown State Prison. The date was February  1946. I wasn't quite 21. I had not yet begun to  shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HAS GONE IN for a TIGHT CLOSE SHOT of Malcolm's fa hustler, pimp, dope peddler and now jailbird at the ripe FREEZE FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the afternoon lockup: about 3:30 P.M. The line of P stands in front of their cells, as two guards, WILKINS an white, one black, slowly walk past the P.M. check.  The procedure is routine, done without emotion, as it is times a day: the black guard calls out the prisoner's nam prisoner answers with his number, then steps into his cel the white guard slams the door shut and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door is slammed and gate locked.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Each time a gate is locked his tension increases. His fac hiding his fury, violence and the hunger of an advanced j not had a fix in over a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are approaching Malcolm's cell. Past Malcolm are two expe PRISONERS who have been watching Malcolm during the scene surreptitiously without moving their bodies, and barely m lips. One of the prisoners is PETE, a huge barrel of a ma beaten by the system and a lifetime of incarceration. The BEMBRY, a man of no great physicality, but who possesses the gift of leadership. It is clear that Pete and others with great respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry's language is very unhip. He speaks carefully. He and he respects himself, something which sets him apart f other prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not gonna bust. But he's not gonna fix  his face to please them, neither. ANGLE. The check-in has reached the man next to Malcolm. GUARD WILKINS

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: The guards are now in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. Bembry in the FG of the scene.  BEMBRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a new fish, Mr. Barnes. Give him a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bold step by Bembry and the prisoners look over at admiration. Barnes accepts the irregularity and calls ove GUARD BARNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0kay, I'll give him a break. Now state your  number, Little.

dialogues.speaker: BEMBRY
dialogues.text: Shaking his head in anguish. He knows what's coming.  ANGLE. Barnes makes a small gesture and Wilkins seizes Ma grabbing his head and uniform at the same time. Stenciled of his faded dungarees is Malcolm's number. The guard ben head to the number, shoving the material in Malcolm's fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you read, boy? Thass your number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Malcolm Little, not no goddam number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes you is, baby; thass all you is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And slams Malcolm hard. He slumps to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days in the hole. Take him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins drags Malcolm off as Barnes resumes the roll call

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the faintest light comes into the hideous room, whic a mattress and a slop bucket. If Malcolm were to stretch he could touch both walls. He lies half on the stone floo mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clang as the heavy door is opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's up. Get on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as Malcolm stares at the man, refusing to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just drew two more days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is almost pitch black. We can almost smell the stench Malcolm sits stony-faced, his back against a wall.  TRUSTEE'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long spigot of a watering can is pushed through an op the cell door. Malcolm, animal-like, leaps at it and bend wrenching it off in his fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what a friend you have in Jesus,  son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher, take your tin Jesus and the Virgin  Mary, both, and shove 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is alone at the bars: the hope of freedom filling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm pulls at the bars, tries to shake them in impoten pounds the walls. Empty, sick, defeated, his nails scratc walls, he slides to the floor of the cell. It is the low point of his life: nowhere to turn, nothing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guard Cone is shaking him into consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm just about makes it. The guard is in half-focus.  GUARD CONE (contd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm stands with bowed head as the hot water cascades broken body. He lets it run and run, but it cannot really problems. On a nearby bench are his clothes, his towel an for a conk: lye, Vaseline, comb, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns for a moment as he sees he is being watched by s Bembry standing nearby. Malcolm turns away, trying to fin the water. He wants no part of the world or anyone, just alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel. Like you want to lay down  and die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm shows no flicker of interest or understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down a small matchbox on the bench next to Malcol Malcolm eyes him like a snake -- but the punishment has r deep insecurity and his belligerence is more cautious tha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it in a cup of water. It's nutmeg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need something. It's not a reefer, but  it'll help some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, get outa my face. I ain't nobody's punk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he steps out of the shower, fills a tin cup with wate the contents of the matchbox into it. And drinks it down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down or it might knock you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm sits, toweling himself as the spice hits him. For smiles; this is the first relief he has tasted in prison. wonderingly, unable to figure him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ain't trying to punk me, what's your  hype?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can show you how to get out of prison. And  it's no hype.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk, daddy, I'm listening. Hey that ain't bad.  You got some more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last stuff you'll ever get from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you give it to me for then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you needed it. 'Cause you couldn't hear  me without it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a new breed of cat; Malcolm has never met anyone eyes him closely, as he slips into his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to conk his hair, but is paying attention to wh saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you got more sense than any cat in this  prison. How come you are such a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody can bust out like Bogart does it, in the movies. Because even if you get out, you are  still in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is putting the conk into his hair now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you go busting your fists against a stone  wall, you're not using your brains. Cause  that's what the white man wants you to do. Look  at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These last words are spoken sharply with disgust. Malcolm hands massaging the conk into his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting all that poison in your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you been locked up too long, everybody  conks. All the cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I don't want to walk around with my head  all nappy, looking like--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what? Looking like me? Like a nigger?!  Why don't you want to look like what you are?  What makes you ashamed of being black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the water on to wash out the conk -- which has b Bembry restrains him, holding his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leggo. I got to wash it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it burn. Maybe you'll hear me then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you better get off me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrenches away from Bembry and puts his head in the wat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, burn yourself, pain yourself, put all  that poison into your hair, into your body --  trying to be white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I don't want to hear all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you was smart. But you just another  one of them cats strutting down the avenue in  your clown suit with all that mess on you. Like  a monkey. And the white man sees you and he  laughs. He laughs because he knows you ain't  white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is drying his hair, finishing his conk. But some has said disturbs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is completely humiliated. Bembry sees this and st barrage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is, who are you? You are in the  darkness, but it's not your fault. Elijah  Muhammad can bring you into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah Muhammad can get you out of prison. Out  of the prison of your mind. Maybe all you want  is another fix. I thought you were smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he is gone. Malcolm stands looking after him, a long moment. He is pulling the comb through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRISONERS are working on a beltline that stamps out and f license plates. Bembry is on the stamping machines, worki to the other prisoners. Malcolm is painting the plates, a removed from Bembry, but listening with interest. Barnes, idles by a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whistle sounds, ending the work shift. The inmates quic into the yard. Bembry stays. Malcolm is half decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you sniffing around for? I told you I gave  you your last fix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't never seen a cat like you. Ain't you  scared talking like that in front of an ofay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he gonna do to me he ain't already done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the only cat don't come on with that  "Whatcha know, daddy" jive; and you don't cuss  none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I respect myself. A man cuss because he hasn't  got the words to say what's on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you this: you ain't no fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't con me. Don't try... MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do with your time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read. I study. Because the first thing a  black man has to do is respect himself. Respect  his body and his mind. Quit taking the white  man's poison into your body: his cigarettes,  his dope, his liquor, his white woman, his  pork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Mama used to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mama had sense because the pig is a filthy  beast: part rat, part cat, and the rest is dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has been pondering all this and now grows animate he has come to the essence of a hustle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, daddy, pull my coat. What happens if  you give all that up? You get sick or somethin'?  I pulled a hustle once and got out of the draft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you God's words, not no hustle. I'm  talking the words of Elijah, the black man's  God. I'm telling you, boy, that God is black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Everybody knows God is White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But everything the white man taught you, you  learned. He told you you were a black heathen  and you believed him. He told you how he took  you out of darkness and brought you to the  light. And you believed him. He taught you to  worship a blond, blue-eyed God with white skin -- and you believed him. He told you black was  a curse, you believed him. Did you ever look  up the word black in the dictionary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever study anything wasn't part of  some con?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, fool; the marble shooters are waiting  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE CAN READ the fine print of the definition:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black, (blak), adj. Destitute of light, devoid  of color, enveloped in darkness. Hence, utterly  dismal or gloomy, as "the future looked black."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULLBACK TO SHOW Bembry and Malcolm in a small PRISON LIB else is in the book-lined room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make out that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soiled with dirt, foul; sullen, hostile,  forbidding -- as a black day. Foully or  outrageously wicked, as black cruelty.  Indicating disgrace, dishonor or culpability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, they's some shit, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry turns the pages of the dictionary to "w."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White (whit), adj. Of the color of pure snow;  reflecting all the rays of the spectrum. The  opposite of black, hence free from spot or  blemish; innocent, pure, without evil intent,  harmless. Honest, square-dealing, honorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm stumbles through the definition as well as he can over the reading, giving it ironic emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bullshit. That's a white man's book.  Ain't all these white man's books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sure ain't no black man's books in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what you telling me to study in them for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to learn everything the white man says  and use it against him. The truth is laying  there if you smart and read behind their words.  It's buried there. You got to dig it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, how'm I gonna know the ones worth looking  at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry smiles at Malcolm. He is a remarkable man who alwa careful measure of his listener. He never talks down to h he talks to them. (A manner Malcolm later will adopt.) Be funky or salty or, as we will see, in the cadence and elo Bible. Right now he goes into street talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pull your coat, daddy. Cause lots of these  can't nobody read, be he black or white or a  Ph.D. with their suspenders dragging the ground  with degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm laughs. He likes and admires the man. Then caught he does not understand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I'm studying in the man's book. I don't dig  half the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look 'em up and and out what they mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start at the beginning. Page one, the first  one. Here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bembry's hand opens the book to page one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aardvark, noun. An earth pig; an ant-eating  African mammal. Man, that sounds like the  dozens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it and keep on reading.  Malcolm's finger runs down to the next definition:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abacus, noun. An ancient and primitive Chinese  counting device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you take one step toward Allah, He will take  two steps toward you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is reading on his bunk as Barnes walks by. The lights out. Malcolm looks up, annoyed at being interrupted. He s position to the floor of the cell so that he can catch th coming from the corridor and goes on with his reading.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK
dialogues.text: Malcolm is studying the dictionary, the last of the "a's" azimuth, Azores, Aztec, azure, etc. He reads a word, then hand over the printed definition to test himself, half-mo meaning. Malcolm is also copying the dictionary in a scho for word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are several books on the desk before Malcolm. WE SE titles: W.E.B. DuBois's _The Soul of Black Folks_, Carter _Journal of Negro History_, Durant's _Story of Philosophy Wells's _Outline of History_, Spinoza, Thoreau, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is surprised the time has gone so fast. He gather with care. He cherishes them, putting them back on the sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You studying to be the first colored  President of the States?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machines are idle; no one is in the room but Malcolm. to reach inside his jacket when Barnes sticks his head in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You taking the yard or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm takes out a half-filled pack of cigarettes, about then pauses. Malcolm hands him the pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take 'em. I don't smoke no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the pack happily and goes. Malcolm reaches into again, takes out a book. WE SEE its title: Mahatma Gandhi Struggle_. He sits next to the license press to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baseball game is in progress. A BLACK TEAM is playing a Most of the CONVICTS are watching the game; partisanship pitch. A base hit gets a big reaction.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM AND BEMBRY
dialogues.text: They are out along the right field wall. They walk throug ANGLE - The ball is hit over the fence for a home run. Th cheer from the black prisoners. Pete, the batter, trots p the bases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ole Pete ain't much in the head, but he can lay  in there with the wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme tell you about history: black history.  You listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO-SHOT - Malcolm still watching the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first men on earth were black. They ruled  and there was not one white face anywhere. But  they teach us that we lived in caves and swung  from trees. Black men were never like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is listening to Bembry's intent statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were a race of kings when the white men went  around on all fours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a crack of the bat and Malcolm turns to watch an hit, by a black convict, stir the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This a helluva game. Somethin's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees a black convict, CHUCK, nearby and calls over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 to 1; we murdering them, Din't you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brooklyn Dodgers brought up Jackie Robinson  and we pounding the hell out of them,  celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, white man throw us a bone and that's  supposed to make us forget 400 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black man playing big league ball is  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to go behind the words and dig out  the truth. They let us sing and dance and  smile -- and now they let one black man in the  majors. That don't cancel out the greatest  crime in history. When that blue-eyed devil  locked us in chains -- 100,000,000 of us --  broke up our families, tortured us, cut us off  from our language, our religion, our history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the stands, cheering and joyous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they know who they are? Do you know where  you came from? We are the Original People.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is listening to him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is startled; answers like a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's the name of the slave-master who  owned your family. You don't even know who you  are. You're nothing. Less than nothing. A zero.  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not Malcolm Little and I'm not Satan.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Malcolm cannot answer because he truly does not know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ball is hit. Malcolm watches its flight but his face is somewhere between understanding and anger: it is the face leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you we are a nation, the lost Tribe of  Shabazz in the wilderness of North America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rays of the sun come through bars that cut across Mal Bembry's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah has sent us a prophet, a black man named  Elijah Muhammad. For if God is black, Malcolm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd hear me. The white man is the  devil. All white men are devils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Elijah Muhammad does not say "that white  man is a devil." He teaches us that the white  man is the devil. All white men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever known a good white man in all  your life? Think back, did you ever meet one  who wasn't evil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm and Bembry standing close together. The feeling i taking communion: with Bembry the minister and Malcolm th Their voices are little more than whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body is a holy repository.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not touch the white man's poison: his  drugs, his liquor, his carrion, his women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Muslim must be strikingly upright.  Outstanding. So those in the darkness can see  the power of the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the key to Islam is submission. That is why  twice daily we turn to Mecca, to the Holy of  Holies, to pray. We bend our knees in submission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry kneels in a praying position. Malcolm stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt,  implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing  on earth--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to, Bembry, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt,  implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing  on earth--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to, Bembry, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say to Allah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever bent your knees, Malcolm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. When I was picking a lock to rob  somebody's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can grovel and crawl for sin, but not to  save your soul. Pick the lock, Malcolm; pick  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to. God knows I want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm holds a letter in his hand. He reads it carefully it several times before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I received a letter that day from the Honorable  Elijah Muhammad. The Messenger of Allah wrote  me, a nobody, a junkie, a pimp and a convict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come to give you something which can  never be taken from you: I bring you a sense of  your own worth, the worth of one human being.  The knowledge of self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room becomes transformed. It is suddenly suffused wit standing in the cell with Malcolm is ELIJAH MUHAMMAD. He materialized, but he can be seen through. He is MALCOLM'S HALLUCINATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like a blinding light and I became aware  that he was in the room with me. He wore a dark  suit and on his face I saw a pain so old and  deep and black I could scarcely look at him. I  knew I was not dreaming. He was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you that the most dangerous creation of  any society in the world is the man with  nothing to lose. You do not need ten such men  to change the world. One will do. The Earth  belongs to us, the Black man and whatever is  around it, and on it and in it. Praises are  due to him forever for bringing to us again,  our self and our property, the UNIVERSE OF SUN,  MOON, AND STARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly as he came, he was gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm goes down on his knees. There are tears in his ey begins praying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah Akbar: all praise to Him who is  all-seeing, all-understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are told that Saul, on the road to Damascus,  heard the words of truth, he fell from his  horse. I do not liken myself to Paul, but I  understand. It happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poorly furnished, small, but immaculate room. There are a table set for eating, and, on the walls, a portrait of Muslim banner. It is dinner time in a Muslim home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIDNEY, aged 20, a perfect specimen of the Fruit of Islam behind his chair, waiting. Their mother, LORRAINE, a woma age, is seated, but she, too, awaits Bembry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of Allah, the beneficent and the  merciful to whom all praise is due.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the window Bembry saying the evening prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Brother Malcolm: I am back in the bosom of  Islam, praise Allah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to the table, nods and sits. Sidney respectfully him. Food is passed. It is simple fare: natural foods, mi The portions are small. They eat in silence, but there is love at this table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We don't have much, but what we have is  yours. Lorraine and my two sons join with me in  saying that when you come out, which will not  be too long, come straight to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is reading Bembry's letter as he waits his turn. WHITE CONVICT in the chair, just being finished by a WHIT SIMMONS. A BLACK BARBER - SLIM sits by. Both are convicts Malcolm now wears glasses, all that reading in his badly ruined his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write thanking me. Don't thank me. Praise  Allah. He did it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm starts for the chair. Simmons moves away to light as Slim takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Bembry. Please thank the Honorable Elijah  Muhammad for the money and tell him I have not  written him because I have not yet proven  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie and Cadillac are reading a letter they have receiv at each other incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have written everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shorty is waving a letter he has received to his CELLMATE SHORTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look like Homey got himself a brand new hype.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immaculate room, well furnished. ELIJAH sits in a chai stands reading Malcolm's letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I wrote the Mayor, the Governor and the  President, but for some reason I haven't heard  from them"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the Messenger of Allah that I have  dedicated my life to telling the white devil  the truth to his face. I greet you with the  ancient words: "As Salaam Alikum."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.S. I finally worked my way through the  "Z's"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP OF PRISONERS, mostly white, but with a goodly sma black convicts, are listening to a lecture by CHAPLAIN GI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. Malcolm seated next to a black convict, raises his the only hand up. The Chaplain searches for another quest there aren't any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, sitting next to Malcolm, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out, baby, this cat is heavy on religion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see this has become a struggle between good  and evil. Satan has a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is laughter from the convicts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is, Chaplain Gill. But I wouldn't want  to say which one of us is what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter, especially from the black convicts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just ask your question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been talking about the disciples. What  color were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we know for certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are reactions from the convicts. Malcolm is sharply white man about color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jesus was. Jesus was also a Hebrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What color were the original Hebrews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you we don't know for certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we don't know that God was white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a strong reaction to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just a moment, just a moment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we do know that the people of that region  of Asia Minor, from the Tigris-Euphrates valley  to the Mediterranean, are dark-skinned people.  I've studied drawings and photographs and seen  newsreels. I have never seen a native of that  area who was not black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying anything, preacher. I'm proving  to you that God is black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Note: Try to get footage from _The Last Temptation of Ch Dafoe])

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm opens the door, the room is dark and he sees a sm man standing against the window, he doesn't move. This is who appeared in Malcolm's cell, this is the Honorable Eli Malcolm slowly moves toward him; he is completely humbled presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns from the window to Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, you've been a thief, drug dealer and a pimp and the world is still full of temptation.  When God bragged how faithful Job was, the  devil argued that only God's protective hedge  around him kept him pure, the devil said remove  the hedge and he will curse his maker.  Malcolm, your hedge has been removed and I  believe you will remain faithful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot say anything and he drops his head, he is overw heartfelt emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In contrast to the peaceful family scene, the room is a b activity. Sidney is turning out leaflets on a mimeograph Lorraine is busy making up a mailing list using 3 x 5 fil Bembry is recruiting on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it 1000. We got a lot of fishing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Malcolm, I want you to meet Brother  Earl. He just joined the Nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl moves toward Malcolm and extends his hands. Malcolm warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can always use another good brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a willing servant for Allah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday service has let out and Malcolm, Earl, and Sidney They're trying to convert the Black Christians. Malcolm s the others hand out leaflets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you are Christians, and yet you see  your so-called white Christian brother hanging  black Christians on trees. You say that white  man loves you and yet he has done every evil  act against you. He has everything while he is  living and tells you to be a good slave and  when you die you will have more than he has in  Beulah's land. We so-called Negroes are in  pitiful shape. Get off your knees praying to  a picture of a white, pale blond, and blue-eyed  Jesus. Come out of the sky. Build heaven on  earth. Islam is the black man's true religion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is talking to a CROWD from a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that the white man is the devil. Yes, God  is black and you are made in His image and  don't know it. That's how brainwashed you are. The crowd is listening, caught up in Malcolm's intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brothers and sisters, they tell you you will  sprout wings when you die and fly to heaven.  The Honorable Elijah Muhammad tells you that's  pie in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amid the listeners, watching their response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen a black man who wasn't down  on his knees begging the Lord to give him in  heaven what the white devil enjoys right here  on earth?

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL LISTENERS
dialogues.text: They turn from Malcolm, moving a few steps away, and now audience on an adjacent SPEAKER. He is a young firebrand:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Harlem Council fights for rat control, for  rent control and for community control of our  schools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN CONTINUES to take in ANOTHER SPEAKER, a few feet away street corner is Harlem's Hyde Park, with half a dozen SP haranguing the crowd with half a dozen panaceas. That Mal one among many: SECOND SPEAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the man behind the counter ain't black,  don't go in. Boycott the man. Be black. Think  black. Buy black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to our Temple and hear the truth. Because,  brother and sister, you are dead. Yes you are,  mentally dead, spiritually dead, morally dead.  And we are here to resurrect the black man  back from the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A place where black women come to offer themselves for da SEVERAL ARE SEEN. A WHITE WOMEN comes up to one to interv (bargain with her). Malcolm's voice is heard before he is speaking to the women from a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My beautiful sister, for you are beautiful.  Beautiful because you are black. Because black  is beautiful. You work in the white folks'  kitchen so I don't have to tell you that  they're devils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are putting yourselves on the auction  block, letting them examine you like a horse,  like a slave. The Honorable Elijah Muhammad  teaches that you are black and should be  proud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACE OF ONE BLACK WOMAN, beginning to shake her head in a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SAME WOMAN, now at a Muslim meeting. The faces of oth (from the church and from the maids' market) are scattere audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headquarters itself shows the progress Malcolm has ma better furnished, larger, and the chairs are filled. Bemb and Lorraine are in the back of the room, pleased with th Malcolm stands at a podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not American, we're Africans who happen  to be in America. We were kidnapped and brought  here against our will from Africa. We didn't  land on Plymouth Rock, brothers and sister.  Plymouth Rock landed on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reactions: laughter, interest. Ad lib "That's the truth."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put an end to your begging. No more "Please,  Mr. White Man, Lawdy boss, brush me another  crumb from off your table, kindly, sir."  We  are a nation, a great nation and don't need a  thing from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm scanning the faces of his audience as they react. someone he knows and blurts out boyishly (and winningly):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd turns to Shorty, sitting embarrassedly in the a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on up here, man, and give us some skin.  Here's a man, brothers and sisters, who shot  up with me, who robbed with me, and did time in  the white devil's jailhouse. Stand up, Shorty,  and be counted--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Shorty is trying to hide from the spotlight. Malcolm from the platform and walks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks, the brother is shy and needs special  attention. So would you excuse us, while Brothers  Sidney and Earl take up the collection. He embraces Shorty as the crowd laughs appreciatively and Sidney and Earl have a chuckle themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly and Malcolm sit at a table. Shorty has a cup of c of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to hand it to you, Homey. That's the best  preacher hype I ever did hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a hype, Shorty. And I meant what I  said: join us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, baby. I don't pay that shit no mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad says you should  pay it all your mind. If you got a mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, I love you. Take it easy, greasy. How  about a snort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been clean for twelve years, Shorty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You is something, Homeboy. My trouble is -- I  ain't had enough stuff yet, I ain't et all the  ribs I want and I sure ain't had enough white  tail yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the rest of the gang? You seen anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Sammy's dead. Yeah, fell over in the bed  with a chick twenty years younger than him. Had  twenty-five grand in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133A         INSERT FLASH - Sammy, he's dead on top of TE screaming, trying to push that dead weight off her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133B         INSERT FLASH - Cadillac is an old junkie, pa staring in a MENTAL WARD, twitching, nose running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooked on horse. Been in and out of Lexington Ave times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133C         INSERT FLASH - Sophia is a bored housewife, cooking while her husband hides behind the Wall Street Jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't seen Archie, but the vine tells it he's  living somewhere's in the Bronx. If you can  call it living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock on the door rouses Archie, by now an old and dyin vigor is gone, all the life has ebbed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git the hell away, you bitch, I'll pay you  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Archie. Archie sits up from his bed and stares. He tries to bring his old juice, tries to stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My man, Red. Come on in, man.  (then giving up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has to help him lie back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really you, Red? The contrast is shocking: Malcolm tall and straight; Arch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saved my life, Archie. Running me out of  Harlem. When I think how close we came to  gunning each other down, I have to thank Allah. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't gonna shoot you, baby. It was just my  rep, that's all. And don't shit me now, but  did you have that number? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It doesn't matter. The thing is  we got to get you back on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I got a couple a new angles ain't been  figured yet. All I need's a stake and a  chance--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you use a few bucks? I ain't got much,  but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, I'm doing okay. Thanks.  MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Lay down and don't think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could of been something, Archie, but the  devil got to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know all the angles except how to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm walks thoughtfully down the street; Archie is sti mind, as he passes prostitute after prostitute. Once beau now selling their bodies. He passes Laura, she has been t out and she looks the part, there is no way he can recogn though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has just gotten a white John and leads him into an al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women who could be mothers, teachers,  scientists...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura kneels down to unzip her John's pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is going to raise our children?; men who  might have been astronauts, composers, engineers; Who is going to be the head of the  households?--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is addressing a HUGE AUDIENCE. His tone is more i personal than before, because of his recent encounters. I audience, sitting with Bembry, is BETTY, a lovely dark-sk Her interest in Malcolm (true, also, for most of the othe sisters) is more than religious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and what has the white devil made of them:  dead souls. Oh, my he has no conscience. He  should fall on his knees and say, "My kind  commits history's greatest crime against your  kind every day of your life." But does he? No.  He scorns you, splits your head with his  nightstick and calls you nigger. If you've had  it, then stand up and come forward. If not us,  then who? If not now, then when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many stand, some walk toward the podium speaking his name you, Brother Malcolm," "Praise Allah," "Me, Brother Malco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is applause; some of the audience get to their feet acknowledges their approval, trying to quiet them, but ca heady excitement of leadership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both are moved by Malcolm's performances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ought to try to make it a little easier,  Brother Bembry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try telling him that, Sister  Betty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Muslim movement has grown enormously. The activity in anteroom, leading to other rooms off it, shows that. Bett stand before a Directory announcing activities in the Tem Fruit of Islam Meeting; TUESDAY - Unity Night; WEDNESDAY Enrollment; THURSDAY - Muslim Girls Training; FRIDAY - Ge Civilization Class; SATURDAY - Swahili, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stir of people and activity as Malcolm enters the anter excuses himself from a group of MUSLIMS, making his way t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Bembry, can we fix it so our  loudspeaker is heard on the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we can. This is a new sister, Sister  Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm nods at her; she nods in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sister lectures our Muslim women in hygiene  and diet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm mutters "very good," but his mind is clearly on a details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sister stresses care of the body and  regular eating habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sister wonders if the Brother knows what  Harriet Tubman did between taking souls to the  Promised Land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is stopped. He looks at Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Sister suggests he put his actions  where his mouth is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
