dialogues.text: Malcolm's laughter is heard, in response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I'll speak to your class. But I'm a hard  man on women. You want to know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm sits next to the Honorable Elijah Muhammad. The s teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women are deceitful. They are untrustworthy  flesh. I've seen too many men ruined or tied  down or messed up by women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty says nothing, she merely pushes the salad plate a l him. The food has thus far gone untouched. Malcolm contin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women talk too much. To tell a woman not to  talk is like telling Jesse James not to carry a  gun or a hen not to cackle. And Samson, the  strongest man that ever lived, was destroyed by  the woman who slept in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I tell my sisters that we oppose  marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We are not Catholic priests. We do not  practice celibacy. If a woman is the right  height for a man, the right complexion, if her  age is half the man's plus seven, if she  understands that man's essential nature is  strong and woman's weak, if she loves children,  can cook, sew and stay out of trouble--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've made your points, Brother  Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you haven't time for either marriage or  eating--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and that women aren't the only ones who  talk a lot.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHERS SIDNEY AND EARL
dialogues.text: They are alarmed at Brother Minister's behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll start eating, there is a question I  have. Go ahead. Start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a forkful of the salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considering today's standards of animal raising  and curing meats, I don't fully understand the  restriction on pork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain. No. I'll do better than that.  I'll show it to you. Scientifically. But it's  demonstration purely in the interest of  science, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand, Brother Malcolm. Purely  scientific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before a comparative evolutionary display showing the ske various animals, Malcolm is holding forth. Betty is dress becoming red dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice especially the claw, the jaw and the  skull formation. This is the rat. This the  mole. Here you have the aardvark and the  boar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is not a matter of the breeding  conditions or preparation of the meat. The meat  itself is foul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. As they saunter out, passing the huge skeletons of animals now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I've had you on your feet for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been on your feet for days. And didn't  even finish your salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the strawberry soda and you're the hot  fudge sundae. He plunks down the order before Betty and Malcolm. Malcol long, long satisfying pull on his straw. Then he sighs:  MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's something I haven't done in fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sat down with a pretty girl and had an ice  cream soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about you for a change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0h, yes, there is. I know a lot about you. Brother Bembry briefed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Purely scientific interest I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from Detroit, near where I come from.  You majored in education at Tuskegee. You're  studying nursing and having trouble with your  family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want you to quit the Muslims or they won't  pay your tuition, isn't that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have enough worries of your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, good Sisters are rare. We need every one.  Tell me something: how tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's just idle, I won't answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a bite of her sundae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Brother Bembry says I'm tall enough for a  tall man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a few things you don't know about  women, Brother Malcolm. They're possessive and  vain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And dogged when I set my mind to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you set your mind to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being a good Muslim, a good nurse and a good  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm takes a good look at the lovely woman in front of long sip from his ice cream soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. As Sidney runs to them at the table:  SIDNEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Johnson was attacked by the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a scuffle. The Brother was watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm listening as SEVERAL WITNESSES simultaneously des attack. A small angry CROWD has gathered. The most animat BENJAMIN, a very dark young black teenager, we will soon later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brother didn't scatter fast enough for the  ofay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack. He bled like a stuck hog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll rap a little. He's a Muslim. And make a  speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muslims talk a good game, but they never do  nothing, unless somebody bothers Muslims. Malcolm's face goes taut. He nods sharply at Sidney, as B watches them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I demand to see Brother Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm facing a DESK SERGEANT, TWO UNIFORMED COPS and a off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police respond with a squeeze play intended to intimi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels the power play and stiffens in resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Minister Malcolm X. Two witnesses saw him  brought in. He was not brought out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look out that window. I intend to see  Brother Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops eye each other. Plainclothes walks to the window 143        EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE - LATE P.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across from the station is a phalanx of some FIFTY MEN of of Islam. All are dressed in dark suits with white shirts in military formation: eyes forward, every face burning. the neighborhood have formed a crowd behind and around th OUT Benjamin among the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cops examine the police blotter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We got a Muslim. The relief must of put it  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't see him. You ain't his lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until I'm satisfied Brother Johnson is  receiving proper medical attention, no one will  move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops eye each other. Plainclothes nods slightly, he has t Malcolm is not playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of Malcolm's head, as he examines Brother Johnso up OUT OF FRAME, WE SEE that Johnson has been badly beate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a pig could do a thing like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you call me boy, you pig. Letting a man  bleed like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant puts a restraining hand on Plainclothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man belongs in a hospital. Get an ambulance.  Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Johnson's body, on a stretcher, is hurried into an amb crowd has grown in proportions. There are ad libs: "Godda police brutality," "Least they got him out of the meat ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm with the Sergeant and a LIEUTENANT, as the ambula

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, break it up. You got what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm starts walking down the center of the street, aft ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fruit of Islam fall in behind him, marching slowly. I start of a march as the neighborhood people fall in behin (especially kids) race with them on the street and on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin fights his way through the crowd trying to walk the Brothers in the Fruit stop him and Benjamin drops bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the march has taken over the broad avenue. COPS are f redirect traffic, holding up crosstown cars as the group by. The people walking behind have swelled it to a huge d Their faces reflect their anger and their satisfaction th something is being done about what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT SHOWS the Muslim men in perfect order, calm wit folded across their chests, waiting. Their eyes are on Ma walks toward the hospital entrance.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: --of the growing crowd. --of the nervous cops, including some big brass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --of kids watching from a rooftop. --of Benjamin trying to emulate the Fruit of Islam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is standing in front of the Fruit of Islam men, a POLICE OFFICER GREEN comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, that's enough. I want these people  moved out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all disciplined men. They're doing  nothing except waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unruly crowd behind the Fruit of Islam. They are rest ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your headache, Captain. And if he dies,  I pity you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll live. He's getting the best care we can  give.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to put a plate in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, okay. Now disperse this mob.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM, FRUIT OF ISLAM AND CROWD
dialogues.text: It's clear the decision is in one man's hands, Malcolm's.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: He makes a gesture with his hand, the Fruit of Islam disp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. People moving away, going home. Only one person re Fruit of Islam and the crowd, it's Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too much power for one man to have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is in a somber mood over the evening's events.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Malcolm sits with Brothers Earl and Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Minister, we need to strike back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to also, but until we are instructed by  the Messenger to do so, we will just wait and  pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin comes into the cafeteria and everyone looks at h Malcolm sitting and moves toward his table.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Brothers Sidney and Earl get up to intercept him but Malc through. Benjamin stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm pours some cream into his cup of black coffee, th white sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is only one thing I like integrated. My  coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. X, I was out there tonight. I saw what you  did. I want to be a Muslim. I ain't never seen  a Negro stand up to the police like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it means to be a true Muslim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly, but I want to be one, like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admire your enthusiasm but you should never  join any organization without first checking it  out thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin is crushed and he starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need more young warriors like yourself,  stick around and we shall see if your heart is  true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. X, I won't make you out a liar.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM X WINS
dialogues.text: An AIDE of Elijah puts down the newspaper and shakes Malc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad would like to see  you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah is sweeping the floor with a plain hand broom. Mal the room, is surprised and waits at the door. The two are together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I surprise you, let me explain. Menial work  teaches us humility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, each of us must relearn that work is the  only worthwhile thing. Allah has given you a  great gift. Use it wisely, never forgetting  that we are nothing, while He is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sweeping done, they stand together near a table at a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight I shall introduce you as my National  Representative. It will be a difficult task.  Your assignment is to build temples all over  this nation. More work than you have ever done  in your life and you will be in the public eye.  My son, beware of those cameras, they are just  as bad as a narcotic. ANGLE - AIDES and OTHERS come into the room now. They are ELIJAH (contd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the white devil will watch your every  step. Even your own Brothers will become  jealous, and hostile, go slowly. So I offer you  a parable -- regarding your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah picks up a glass and sets it before Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is a glass, dirty and its water foul. If  you offer it to the people and they have no  choice, they must drink out of it. But if you  present them with this glass--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is holding a clean glass, with clear water in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and let them make their decision, they will  choose the pure vessel. Islam is the only  religion which addresses the needs and problems  of the so-called Negro, especially in the  ghettos -- Islam is the only way out from drugs,  crime, unemployment, prostitution, alcohol,  gambling, fornication and adultery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah holds up the clear glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sweet, gentle man gave me the truth from  his own mouth. And I adored him, in the sense  of the Latin root of the word. Adorare, to  worship and to fear. He was the first man I  ever feared -- not fear such as the one has of  a gun but the fear one has of the power of the  sun, I pledged myself to him, even if it cost  me my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is administering to a PATIENT, as a phone is heard answered. ANOTHER NURSE motions Betty to the phone. She f her patient and goes quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I did. Did you hear my answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. Can you catch a plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Malcolm sit on the floor in the dimlit room, ve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're with me even when you're away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He embraces her. Then Betty laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never told you, but when I first saw you on  the podium, cleaning your glasses, I felt sorry  for you. Nobody as young as you should be that  serious. But I don't think that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The simplest thing in the world: I want to have  a lot of babies with you. Dear Heart, I love  you. Full embrace. BEMBRY'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're waiting on you folks. You trying to starve  us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has just cut the cake and handed a slice to Betty laughter and great warmth, Sidney unfurls the front page _Messenger_, the Muslim newspaper. Headline reads: "MALCO BETTY SAUNDERS." Betty kisses her husband and Bembry, Lor Sidney, Peter and VARIOUS BROTHERS AND SISTERS applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We notice the subtle change in the apartment: it is more there is even evidence of some small luxury: a TV set, a etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is speaking to a GOOD SIZED AUDIENCE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must emphasize at the outstart, that the  Honorable Elijah Muhammad is not a politician,  so I'm not here this afternoon as a Republican,  nor a Democrat, not as a Mason nor an Elk, not  as a Christian nor a Jew, not as a Catholic nor  a Protestant, not as a Baptist nor a Methodist,  not even as an American. For if I was an  American the problem that confronts our people  today would not exist. So I stand here as what  I was when I was born: A BLACK MAN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before there were any such things as Democrats  or Republicans, we were black. Before there  were any such things as Masons or Elks, we were black. Before there were any such things  as Jews or Christians, we were black people. In  fact long before there was ever any such place  as America, we were black people... And after  America has long passed from the scene there  will still be BLACK PEOPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is neatly dressed in white shirt, jacket and tie, a fi Muslim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad sits on the stage to the ri This is a larger audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of black people does the Honorable  Elijah Muhammad speak for? Black people who are  jobless... the black masses who are poor,  hungry, and angry, the black masses who are  dissatisfied with the slums and ghettos in  which we have been forced to live... the black  masses who are tired of listening to the  promises of white politicians to correct the  miserable living conditions that exist in our  community... the black masses that are sick of  the inhuman acts of bestial brutality practiced  by these semi-savage white policemen that  patrol our community, like the occupation  forces of a conquering enemy army... the black  masses who are fed up with the anemic, Uncle  Tom leadership set up by the white man to act  as a spokesman for our people and to KEEP US

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the black man cannot go back to his own  people and his own land, Elijah Muhammad is  asking that a part of the United States be  separated and given to the Muslims so they can  live separately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad is the only man  the white people can deal with in the solving  of problems of the so-called Negro...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest room. She is rocking a cradle with her foot as s BETTY'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attallah is fine. Our firstborn is an angel and  a beauty. And misses you as I do. But the news  that you've dedicated four new temples is  almost as good as having you with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm sits in front of a television screen and watches news. The following speech will be INTERCUT with  A SERIES OF OLD NEWSREEL FOOTAGE - BLACK & WHITE  (newsclips from Birmingham, Selma, Mississippi, and elsew 158B        --POLICE using dogs against DEMONSTRATORS.  158C        --The Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King marchin 158D        --Cattle prods used against MEN, WOMEN and CH 158E        --The Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King singing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158F        --PREGNANT WOMAN knocked down by high-pressur 158G        --The Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King leading

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158H        --Students sitting in at a counter. 158I        --The smoldering ruins of Birmingham's 16th S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white people who are guilty of white  supremacy try and hide their own guilt by  accusing the Honorable Elijah Muhammad of  teaching black supremacy when he tries to  uplift the mentality, the social, and economic  condition of black people in this country. And  the Jews, who have been guilty of exploiting  the black people economically, civilly, and  otherwise, hide their guilt by accusing the  Honorable Elijah Muhammad of being anti-Semitic  simply because he teaches our people to go into  business for ourselves and trying to take over  the economic leadership in our own community.  The black people in this country have been the  victims of violence at the hands of the white  man for 400 years, and following the ignorant  Negro preachers, we have thought that it was  God-like to turn the other cheek to the brute  that was brutalizing us. 100 years ago they  use to put on a white sheet and use a  bloodhound against Negroes. Today they've taken off sheets and put on police uniforms, they've  traded in the bloodhounds for police dogs. And  just as Uncle Tom back during slavery used to  keep the Negroes from resisting the bloodhounds  or resisting the Ku Klux Klan by telling them  to love their enemy or pray for those who use  them as spitefully today. The Honorable Elijah  Muhammad is showing black people that just as  the white man and every other person on this  earth has God given rights, natural rights,  civil rights, and any other kind of rights that  you can think of when it comes to defending  himself.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM'S FACE
dialogues.text: With a studio mike around his neck, he's on a panel show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. X, before we start our discussion tonight  -- The Black Muslims: Hate Mongers -- would you  mind explaining for us the meaning of your  name, which is the letter X.

dialogues.speaker: PANEL
dialogues.text: Opposing Malcolm is DR. PAYSON, a NAACP-type NEGRO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. As you know, during slavery time, the  slavemasters named most of the so-called  Negroes in America after themselves. Mr. Elijah  Muhammad teaches us once you come into the  knowledge of Islam, you replace your slave name  with an X. Since we've been disconnected, cut  off from our Eastern culture for so long that  we don't know the names we originally had, we  will use X until we get back to the East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. X is a demagogue. He has no place to go, so  he exaggerates. He's a disservice to every good  law-abiding Negro in the country. Can I ask you  a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Malcolm X, why do you teach black  supremacy? Why do you teach hate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the white man to ask the black man if he  hates him is just like the rapist asking the  raped, or the wolf asking the sheep, "Do you  hate me!" The white man is in no moral position  to accuse anyone of hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Mr. X, you must admit there has been  progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk about "progress" in a minute, but let  me finish with my brother. Malcolm gestures to the Negro panelist.  The BLACK MEMBER audience are lapping it up. Betty and Earl also sit in th audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop me if I'm wrong. I "polarize the community."  I "erroneously appraise the racial picture."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left one phrase out. Another educated  Kneegrew said to me and I quote: "Brother  Malcolm oversimplifies the dynamic interstices  of the Negro subculture." Would you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have this to say. Do you know what a  Negro with a B.A., an M.A. and a Ph.D. is  called -- by the white man? I'll tell you. He's  called a nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is some blanching and guffawing from the audience. is totally embarrassed, Betty roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm not finished. To understand this man--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points a sharp finger at the Negro Panelist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --you must know that historically there are two  kinds of slaves. House Negroes and Field  Negroes. The house Negro lived in the big  house; he dressed pretty good; he ate pretty  good and he loved the master. Yeah, he loved  him more than the master loved himself. If the  master's house caught fire, he'd be the first  to put the blaze out. If the master got sick,  he'd say: "What's a matter, boss; we sick?"  WE sick! If someone said to him, "Let's run  away and escape. Let's separate." He'd say,  "Man, are you crazy? What's better than what I  got here?" That was the House Negro. In those  days he was called the House Nigger. Well,  that's what we call them today because we still  got a lot of House Niggers running around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is applause from the blacks in the audience. Modera regain control.

dialogues.speaker: THE HONORABLE ELIJAH MUHAMMAD
dialogues.text: He is enjoying this display by his prize student, the CAM CLOSE SHOT of BEMBRY and the same cannot be said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think, perhaps, Dr. Payson has something to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to hear about the Field Nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now the Negro in the field caught  hell all day long. He was beaten by the master;  he lived in a shack, wore castoff clothes and  hated his master. If the house caught fire,  he'd pray for a wind. If the master got sick,  he'd pray that he'd die. And if you said to  him, "Let's go, let's separate", he'd yell,  "Yeah, man, any place is better than this."  You've got a lot of Field Negroes in America  today. I'm one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --there's another one. The majority of black  Americans today are Field Negroes. They don't  talk about OUR progress, about OUR government,  OUR navy, OUR astronauts. Hell, they won't  even let you near the plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry turns off the TV set and he commences to plant the "betrayal."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your holy apostle, dear Messenger, I am your  true servant and the brothers asked me to tell  you Malcolm is getting too much press. The  brothers think he thinks _he_ is the Nation of  Islam, that he has aspirations to lead the  Nation. It was you who made Malcolm the man he is. You lifted him out of the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and tell the brothers what Brother Minister  is doing, has done, has been of great benefit  to the Nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is walking the streets of Harlem like he is campa office. He has Brothers Sidney, Earl, and Benjamin at his follows him. Malcolm sees a WINO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Man, put that bottle down, take that  poison away from your lips. That's what the  devil wants you to do, stay high, out of your  natural mind. I know, I've been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wino looks at Malcolm and continues to drink his wine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159H        --Malcolm emerges from a doorway to be met by armed with microphones. He walks; they follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159I        --Malcolm walking in Harlem, urging people to to the meetings, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time you received your X. But first you  must copy this letter, exactly as I give it to  you; down to the dotted "i's," crossed "t's,"  everything. And you must go on a fast, just  water and juices, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the letter from Malcolm and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Benjamin, do not rush, it has to be  exact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Benjamin goes off in a corner and very quickly copies t he's so anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Benjamin hands Malcolm his letter, Malcolm shakes his h it back, it's not exact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is talking to a group of PEOPLE who are having a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you live in a poor neighborhood, you're  living in an area where you have poor schools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm hands him back his letter again. The fast is gett Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you have poor schools you have poor  teachers. When you have poor teachers, you get  a poor education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor education, you only work on poor paying  jobs and that enables you to live again in a  poor neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's a very vicious cycle. We've got to  break it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin weakly walks toward Malcolm and gives him his le takes. The fast is wearing him out.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: His face is filled with apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All praises are due to Allah. Thank you,  Brother Minister.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Benjamin 2X sits with Malcolm and Brothers Earl and Sidne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now sitting with Brother Benjamin 2X.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Minister, can I have something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get this man some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD OF STUDENTS outside the Law School. The setting i the last time we saw Malcolm and Shorty here, except now part for him. Malcolm walks slowly toward the entrance, l the Latin inscription of the building when he is stopped COED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. X, I've read some of your speeches and I  honestly believe a lot of what you say has  truth to it. I have a good heart. I'm a good  person despite my whiteness. What can the good  white people like myself, who are not  prejudiced, or racist, what can we do to help  the cause?

dialogues.speaker: COED
dialogues.text: She is absolutely crushed and runs away in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking to a packed STUDENT AUDIENCE.  MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My high school was the black ghetto of  Roxbury. My college was the streets of Harlem,  and I took my masters in prison. If you look  out the window--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --you can see my burglary hangout. I lived  like an animal. Had it not been for the  Honorable Elijah Muhammad I would surely be in  an insane asylum or dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Muhammad is trying to get us on God's side,  so God will be on our side to help us fight our  battles. When Negroes stop getting drunk, stop  being addicted to drugs, stop fornicating and committing adultery. When we get off the  welfare, then we'll be MEN. Earn what you need  for your family, then your family respects you.  They'll be proud to say "That's my father."  She's proud to say "That's my husband..."  Father means you're taking care of those  children. Just 'cause you made them that don't  mean you're a father. Anybody can make a baby,  but anybody can't take care of them. Anyone can  go and get a woman but anybody can't take care  of a woman. This is the type of teaching that  the honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches us so we  can build the moral fiber of our people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see the gentlemen of the press, also the  FBI and CIA. are with us. Get it straight 'cuz  if I said, "Mary had a little lamb," they'd  write Malcolm X lampoons poor Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud laughter from the audience. But this response is ove the response of ANOTHER, LARGER AUDIENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is talking before an all-black audience. It is th rally yet; the hall is packed to the rafters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have built temples in Boston, in Detroit, in  Atlanta, Philadelphia, Washington -- 100  temples in fifty states. From a handful we  have grown to scores of thousands.

dialogues.speaker: THE RALLY
dialogues.text: HAWKERS selling _The Messenger_, faces of Fruit of Islam podium; Lorraine, Sidney, Earl, Benjamin, and Bembry. For time a new note is seen in Bembry's face: reserve borderi resentment. When others around him cheer Malcolm, Bembry Sidney notices this from his father, but makes no comment MALCOLM/HIS VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Honorable Elijah Muhammad teaches us that  God is now about to establish a kingdom on this  earth based on brotherhood and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: against peace, his history on this earth has  proved that. Nowhere in history has he been  brotherly toward anyone. The only time he has  been brotherly toward you is when he can use  you, when he can exploit you, when he can  oppress you, when you will submit to him. And  since his own history makes him unqualified to  be an inhabitant or a citizen in a kingdom of  brotherhood, the Honorable Elijah Muhammad  teaches us that God is about to eliminate that  particular race from this earth. So since they  are due for elimination, we don't want to be  with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the so-called Negro were American citizens  we wouldn't have a race problem. If the  Emancipation Proclamation was authentic, you  wouldn't have a race problem. If the 13th,  14th, and 15th amendments to the Constitution  was authentic, you wouldn't have a race  problem. If the Supreme Court desegregation  decision was authentic, you wouldn't have a  race problem. All of this is hypocrisy. These  Negro leaders have been telling the white man  everything is all right, everything is under  control. And they've been telling the white man  that Mr. Muhammad is wrong, don't listen to  him. But everything Mr. Muhammad has been  saying is going to come to pass is now coming  to pass and now the Negro leaders are standing  up saying that we are about to have a racial  explosion. We're going to have a racial  explosion and that's more dangerous than an  atomic explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to explode because black people are  dissatisfied. They're dissatisfied now not only  with the white man, but with these Negroes who  have been sitting around here posing as leaders  and spokesmen for black people. Anytime you put  too many sparks around a powder keg, the thing  is going to explode and if the thing that  explodes is still inside the house, then the  house will be destroyed. So the Honorable  Elijah Muhammad is telling the white man get  this powder keg out of your house, let the  black people in this country separate from him  while there's still time. And if the black man  is allowed to separate and go on onto some land  of his own, where he can solve his problems,  then there won't be any explosion. COMPLETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave of cheers as people explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rally is over. A small room packed with PEOPLE congra Malcolm, trying to touch him. He is the hero of the hour. and Benjamin with him, enjoying the accolades and trying Malcolm make his way out. Bembry stands apart, removed an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Brother; Sister, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. A WELL-KNOWN PERSONALITY (DICK GREGORY) is at the Malcolm know each other well. Malcolm extends a palm, but doesn't slap it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't know, man, then I feel sorriest  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, pregnant with child, is in a chair -- a newspaper Malcolm is in the other room, putting his last daughter t hear him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters, a smile on his face, but the concern of the clearly imprinted. He sits down heavily. Betty watches hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long day. Long night. Long year. Long ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear heart, because I know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to bring my troubles home. You  know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to sit here and be still. BETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never had a fight. Not a real one. But  we're going to have one right now if you don't talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always talk, always been talk, and  always will be talk. Don't they say how I'm  trying to take over the Nation, how I'm getting  rich off the Nation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get to that, too, but this isn't just  talk any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the newspaper and reads from it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Los Angeles, UPI: Elijah Muhammad, 67-year-old  leader of the Black Muslim Movement, today  faced paternity suits from two former  secretaries who charged he fathered their four  children..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are always slanders, always lies. You're  reading the devil's lies. Can't you see they're  trying to bring us down, bring down the  Messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Both women, in their 20's, charged they had  had intimacies with Elijah Muhammad since

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to talk to Bembry about it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Bembry? Is Bembry your friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman, have you lost your mind? What's the  matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty gets up, goes to him gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, what's the matter with you? Wake up! Are  you so dedicated that you have blinded  yourself? Are you so committed you cannot face  the truth? Bembry is the editor of the  newspaper you established. Ask him why your  name hasn't been in "Muhammad Speaks" in over a  year? Ask him why you rate front page in every  paper in the country, but not a single sentence  in your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in personal publicity. Our  people know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what Bembry is doing? You're so  blind, everyone can see this but you!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry saved my Life. The Honorable Elijah  Muhammad saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time ago. You've repaid them many times  over. Ask them why they have new cars and  houses full of new furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what this is about? Material wealth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we have, Malcolm. A broken-down jalopy  and the clothes on our backs. We don't even own  our own home. What about our children? What  about me? You don't even own life insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nation will provide for you and the  children if anything happens to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they? Are you sure? Are you sure or are  you blind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear heart, you have to help me. I'm raising  our kids practically by myself, while you're  running all over the world. You don't know how  many times the girls ask me when is daddy  coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do? Our people need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open your eyes, you can face death 24 hours a  day; but the possibility of betrayal never  enters your mind. If you won't do that for  yourself do it for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm knocks on the door of Evelyn Williams, one of the secretaries/wives. She opens the door and has child in he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name is Eva Marie, she's 2 years old.  Brother Minister, I did nothing wrong. I did  nothing to be put in isolation. I believed in  him. I believed in the Honorable Elijah  Muhammad.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: He cannot believe what he is hearing, but he must. The tr his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is sitting holding both of the children. Sister L pregnant with 3rd child waddles across the room to sit do with him. She picks up one of the kids from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Saudi, she's 3 and you have Lisha,  she's 2. Brother Minister the Honorable Elijah  Muhammad is the father of my 3 children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother Minister he often talked about you. He  loves you, loves you like his own son. Says you  are the best, his greatest Minister but that  someday you would leave him and turn against  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am, Brother Minister. All I want is  support for my children. He should provide for  his children. That's all I want.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: He has said everything on his mind and waits for Bembry's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about -- "blackout"? Some  of the Brothers are a little jealous. Maybe  they think you been a little -- overpublicized.  That's all. Forget it. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is listening closely. Bembry puts an arm around h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now about our coming up in the world a little.  You're not naive. You're a man of the world.  The Movement's grown; we've grown with it. You  know folks. They want their leaders to be  prosperous. One hand washes the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm telling you God's words, not to hustle."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a new car? You want a new house? Is  that it? It's the money, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm has to control his rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tell the world we're moral leaders because  we follow the personal example of the Honorable  Elijah Muhammad. It's hard to make a rooster  stop crowing once the sun has risen. The sun is  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, a last-minute replacement for the ailing Honorab Muhammad, speaks before a HUGE CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do I say of this so-called national  mourning! I say... the white man's acts are  condemned, not only by our beliefs but by his  own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both his Bible and the Holy Koran say: "As you  sow, so shall you reap." Both say: "Sow the  wind, reap the whirl wind."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the soil of America the white man planted  the seeds of hate. He allowed the weeds that  sprang up to choke the life out of thousands  of black men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they have strangled one of the gardeners.  This is the justice of Allah. Wa-Salaam Alaikum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minister X! Don't you have even a little bit of  remorse... saddened by President Kennedy's  assassination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assassination might be too good a word, and  might I add an Arabic word at that. This was a  prime example of the devil's chickens coming  home to roost. Being an old farm boy myself,  chickens coming home to roost never did make  me sad. It always made me glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his desk is the black headlines: MALCOLM X CALLS ASSAS "CHICKENS COMING HOME TO ROOST." Elijah's health is getti coughing is frequent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the papers today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a very bad statement. The country  loved this man, and you have made it hard in  general for Muslims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must dissociate ourselves from your terrible  blunder. I'll have to silence you for the next  ninety days. You are not allowed to make any  statements to the press nor are you to speak at  any temples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Elijah, his leader, his friend, his father an total sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with you, sir. I submit 100 percent.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Malcolm turns around and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: As the door is being closed, WE SEE Bembry kneeling befor kissing his hand. The door closes, the SCREEN IS BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney is playing on the floor with the kids. Betty scoop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon girls, it's bedtime. The phone rings. Malcolm answers it. From his expression a threat call. He hangs up. Betty leaves with the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has this been going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All day since you and Betty left. Brother  Minister, I have to level with you. They gave  me a mission. But I couldn't do it. I love  y'all. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To wire your car so it would explode when you  turned the ignition. The Ministers say you are  spreading untruths about the Messenger. The  Ministers say you are a great hypocrite, Judas,  Benedict Arnold. The Ministers say your tongue  should be cut out and delivered to the  Messenger's doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You'll be marked for death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let myself come between you and your  father. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney reluctantly leaves, walks out the door, past Betty him, then Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm -- backed by Brothers Earl and Benjamin 2X -- fac of SUPPORTERS and REPORTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because 1964 threatens to be a very explosive  year on the racial front, and because I myself  intend to be very active in every phase of the  American Negro struggle for HUMAN RIGHTS, I  have called this press conference, this  morning in order to clarify my own position in  the struggle -- especially in regards to  politics and nonviolence. In the past I thought  the thoughts, spoke the words of the Honorable  Elijah Muhammad, that day is over. From now on  I speak my own words, and think my own thoughts.  Internal differences within the Nation of Islam  forced me out of it. I did not leave of my own  free will. But now that it has happened, I  intend to make the most of it. Now that I have  more independence of action, I intend to use a  more flexible approach toward working with  others to get a solution to this problem. I do  not pretend to be a divine man, but I do  believe in divine guidance, divine power, and  in the fulfillment of divine prophecy. I am not  educated, nor am I an expert in any particular  field, but I am sincere, and my sincerity is my  credentials. I'm not out to fight other Negro  leaders or organizations. We must find a common  solution, to a common problem. I am going to  organize and head a new mosque in New York  City, known as the Muslim Mosque, Inc. This  gives us a religious base, and the spiritual  force necessary to rid our people of the vices  that destroy the moral fiber of our community.  Our political philosophy will be black  nationalism. Our economic and social philosophy  will be black nationalism. The Muslim Mosque,  Inc. will remain wide open for ideas and  financial aid from all quarters. Whites can  help us, but they can't join us. There can be  no black-white unity until there is first some  black unity. A host of questions fired all at once: How many of Elijah will join you? etc, etc, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one further preparation I need. It is  a return to the source of our great religion. I  will make a pilgrimage to Mecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, at the window, as his plane takes off. He is wat and the children on the Visitors' Ramp. He sees her becom figure, waving a vivid bandana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is out of sight. Betty gathers up her children. she is subtly surrounded by the protecting BAND OF SUPPOR Earl and Benjamin 2X.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My darling Betty. Everywhere I go I am welcomed  as the representative of our people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches as Malcolm walks between the two pyramids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our fight is known and respected worldwide.  Incidentally, there's a little white man who  follows me wherever I go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a camel as he rides toward the Sphinx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder who he's working for? If I was a  betting man, I'd say CIA. What's your guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I arrived in Jedda, Saudi Arabia. I have never  witnessed such sincere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is reading Malcolm's letter to a LARGE AUDIENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...hospitality and true brotherhood as  practiced here in the ancient home of Abraham,  Mohammad and the great prophets of the  Scriptures..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Malcolm, wearing the garb of a pilgrim, walks with a VA OTHERS, similarly clad, around the Great Temple. He wears towels, one over his loins, the other over his neck and s leaving the right arm and shoulder bare. He wears simple other pilgrims are of various colors: from white, to yell black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 177B        --Malcolm and SEVERAL WHITE PILGRIMS eating M chicken and shaking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 177C        --Malcolm and OTHERS walking around the Great in the middle of the Great Mosque. He falls to his knees. he describes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, with thousands of others, I proclaimed  God's greatness in the Holy City of Mecca.  Wearing the Ihram garb I made my seven circuits  around the Kaaba; I drank from the well of Zem  Zem; I prayed to Allah from Mt. Ararat where  the Ark landed. It was the only time in my life  that I stood before the Creator of all and felt  like a complete human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elijah and a GROUP OF BLACK MUSLIM LEADERS. Bembry among like he is the number two man now that Malcolm has been j Messenger lies in bed, he is having a coughing fit, this condition he's been in. A DOCTOR orders everyone out the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be shocked by these words, but I have  eaten from the same plate, drunk from the same  glass and prayed to the same God with fellow  Muslims whose eyes were blue, whose hair was  blond and whose skin was the whitest of whites.  And we are brothers, truly; people of all  colors and races believing in One God and one  humanity. Once before, in prison, the truth  came and blinded me. It has happened again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is with Brothers Earl, Benjamin 2X, and the childre now four including another BABY - GAMILAH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the past, I have permitted myself to be used  to make sweeping indictments of all white  people, and these generalizations have caused  injuries to some white folks who did not  deserve them. Because of the spiritual rebirth  which I was blessed to undergo as a result of  my pilgrimage to the Holy City of Mecca, I no  longer subscribe to sweeping indictments of  one race. I intend to be careful not to  sentence anyone who has not been proven guilty.  I'm not a racist and do not subscribe to any of  the tenets of racism. In all honesty and  sincerity it can be stated that I wish nothing  but freedom, justice and equality: life,  liberty, and the pursuit of happiness for all  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 179A         SHOT. Malcolm is bent over in prayer, lone f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first concern, of course, is with the group  to which I belong, the Afro-Americans, for we,  more than any other, are deprived of these  inalienable rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 179B         SHOT. Malcolm on a plane headed home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe the true practice of Islam can remove  the cancer of racism from the hearts and souls  of white Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TIGHT TWO-SHOT of Malcolm and Betty in an embrace. She him and whispers: "Go ahead. I can wait now."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large PRESS CONFERENCE: mikes of every network, every n wire service present. Malcolm sports a beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, you said on your trip abroad you  sensed a feeling of great brotherhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I recall, I pointed out that while I was in  Mecca making the pilgrimage, I spoke about the  brotherhood that existed at all levels among  all people, all colors who had accepted the  religion of Islam. I pointed out that what it  had done, Islam, for those people despite their  complexion differences, that it would probably  do America well to study the religion of Islam  and perhaps it could drive some of the racism  from this society. Muslims look upon themselves  as human beings, as part of the human family  and therefore look upon all other segments of  the human family as part of that same family.  Today my friends are black, brown, red, yellow  and white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, are you prepared to go to the United  Nations at this point and ask that charges be  brought against the United States for its  treatment of the American Negroes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience will have to be quiet. Yes, as I  pointed out that during my trip that nations,  African nations, Asian, Latin nations look very  hypocritical when they stand up in the UN  condemning South Africa and saying nothing  about the racist practices that are manifested  everyday against Negroes in this society. I  would be not a man if I didn't do so. I  wouldn't be a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you prepared to work with some of the  leaders of some of the other civil rights organizations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, we will work with any groups,  organizations or leaders in any way, as long as  it's genuinely designed to get results.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the new beard have any religious  significance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not particularly. But I do think that you  will And black people in America, as they  strive to throw off the shackles of mental  colonialism, will also probably reflect an  effort to throw off the shackles of cultural  colonialism. And then they'll begin to reflect  desires of their own with standards of their  own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of your more controversial remarks was a  call for black people to get rifles and form  rifle clubs sometime back. Do you still favor  that for self-defense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why that should be controversial. I  think that if white people found themselves  victim of the same kind of brutality that black  people in this country face, and they saw that  the government was either unwilling or unable  to protect them, that the intelligence on the  part of the whites would make them get some  rifles and protect themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the white man changed since I went away?  Have you put up your guns? The day you stop  being violent against my people will be the  day I tell folks to put away their guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git your hand out of my pocket! Everyone turns around to the back to see what the commoti The man who yelled out leaves quickly, we will see him la soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm looks out the living room window, he has a rifle (NOTE: This is the same pose as the famous photograph of doesn't see anyone and closes the curtain. The phone ring

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Betty has picked up also and she's listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're days on this earth are numbered, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm enters the room and gets into the bed with Betty, ear down on his wife's pregnant stomach. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to sleep for three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm pulls Betty closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I haven't been the best husband or  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Families shouldn't be separated. I'll never  make another long trip without you and the kids.  We'll all be together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had the best organization that black people  ever had and niggers ruined it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a cold winter night. A Molotov cocktail is lit and the front picture glass window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm grabs his pistol and quickly throws a coat over B half-asleep, frightened, trembling and disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk out the back, dear. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty goes. Malcolm runs back for the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. He reassuringly leads the four children, in their through the smoke-filled house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be afraid of. It might be a  little cold. Hang on. We'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE CUT BACK TO Earl Little getting his family out of the in Lansing, Michigan. It should be the same exact scene w earlier in the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody out. OUT! OUT! Get the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighbors' lights have gone on. There are shouts: "What i "Bring those children in here."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hose is playing on the fire. Police cars have arrived. REPORTERS with the COPS. Malcolm faces them furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the fire hit the window and it woke up my  second oldest baby, but the fire burned on the  outside of the house. It could have fallen on  six-, four-, or two-year-old girls. And I'm  going to tell you, if it had done it, I'd've  taken my rifle and gone after anybody in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was bombed by the Black Muslim movement upon  the orders of Elijah Muhammad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what Muslim headquarters is saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can imagine. I did it myself. For the  publicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bembry is being interviewed by a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We feel this is a publicity stunt on the part  of Malcolm X. We hope this isn't a case of "if  he can't keep the house, we won't get it  either."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car comes roaring down the street with rifles sticking windows, and pulls right up in front of Malcolm's house.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: Brothers Earl and Benjamin 2X run out of the car up to Ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We called your house, operator said you had  requested that your phone be turned off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about myself, my wife and four  children were sleeping in their beds, they  have nothing to do with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of this cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers Earl and Benjamin take off their coats and put i and lead him to a police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE BLACK MEN sit around a table. They do not speak. The Hayer, Ben Thomas, Leon Davis, William X and Wilbur Kinle Muslims, all are the ASSASSINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a roll of exposed 35mm film into a sock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is checking in when he is approached by a young W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. X. I have a good heart. I'm a good person  despite my whiteness. What can the good white  people like myself who are not prejudiced do to  help the cause of the Negro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. He thinks. He speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let sincere white individuals find other white  people who feel as they do and teach  non-violence to those whites who think and act  so racist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Mr. X, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's all pray without ceasing. May Allah bless  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm lies on his bed, and for the first time WE SEE th his face, it has begun to take its toll, he's a haunted m man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, where are you? We've been calling all  over the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT between Malcolm and Brother Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna try and get some work done tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let some of us come down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that won't be necessary. I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd listen to us. What about the  meeting tomorrow? We need to frisk people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want folks to be searched, it makes  people uncomfortable. If I can't be safe among  my own kind, where can I be? Allah will protect  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five assassins are casing ballroom. They check the di entrances, the exits, the bathrooms, staircases while the crowd continues to dance the night away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is putting her four daughters to sleep when the pho picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That red nigger of yours is dead and so are  your bastard children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty hangs up the phone and it rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop calling us. Leave us alone. Leave us alone.  I'll kill you. I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT between between Malcolm and Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, they keep calling, threatening us.  I'm going crazy, when is this going to stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't answer the phone. It's all right. It's  all right. Nothing is gonna happen to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Hilton. The girls asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just put them to bed. Can we come to the  meeting tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blue 1968 Cadillac passes a sign that says Patterson, N

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: The assassins are on their way to the Audubon Ballroom, W is behind the wheel, no one is talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is driving to the Audubon Ballroom, her four daught backseat making a racket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm drives to the Audubon Ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers Earl and Benjamin 2X along with some others are folding chairs in place for the coming meeting. The audie started to come in yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assassins are driving over the George Washington Brid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers, the time is fast approaching, it's  the hour of the knife.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Betty is trying to quiet down her daughters as she drives

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is in deep thought as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and her four kids walk into the ballroom and move d aisle. One of the girls drops her black doll and a young up. The young man is Thomas Hayer, he gives it back to he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE. The rest of the assassins come in and go to their along with the rest of the crowd, the place is starting t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of the minister yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm drives past the Audubon Ballroom, people are goin cops are present.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Malcolm parks his car, it's four blocks away. He turns of and sits there.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It's as if he's frozen in his car.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Malcolm finally gets out of the car, locks the door and w of steps, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Malcolm has stopped in his tracks, like some unseen force him which prevents him from moving. Malcolm is paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are closed, and the street noise begins to build deafening _roar_. Then all of a sudden it stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm opens his eyes, she has brought him out of it. He but doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm looks at this old woman, who slightly resembles h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. We need you. I recognize you, don't pay  them folks no never mind, you keep on doing  what you doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pray for you too, son. Jesus will protect  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away, carrying her two shopping bags full of gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm walks in. Present are Brothers Earl, Benjamin 2X secretary SISTER ROBIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You've had ample time, you and the  sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize Brother Minister, we'll have it  next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks are sitting out there _today_, not next  week, expecting to hear our program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the Reverend called? Is he going to show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Chickenwing called last night and said  he wouldn't be able to attend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now we have no opening speaker? Why wasn't I  informed last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called Sister Betty, she didn't tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you start telling Sister Betty my  business? Since when? She has nothing to do  with this. You tell me, not her, not anybody  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you about assuming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm starts pacing the room, nobody has ever seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, you better go out there and explain  why the program isn't ready today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister, please go with the brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way I feel, I ought not to go out there  today. In fact, I'm going to ease some of this  tension by telling the black man not to fight  himself -- that's all a part of the white man's  big maneuver, to keep us fighting amongst  ourselves, against each other. I'm not  fighting anyone, that's not what we're here  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone COP in uniform stands in the shadows with a walkie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm is about to go on stage when he sees Sister Robin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to forgive me for raising my voice  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is filled. Betty and the girls sit in a boxed-o near the platform. Malcolm's bodyguards stand on and arou Benjamin 2X is finishing up his speech when Malcolm walks stage and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, without further remarks, I present to  you one who is willing to put himself on the  line for you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --a man who would give his life for you. I want  you to hear, to listen, to understand one who  is a Trojan for the black man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roar greets Malcolm's intro. He shakes hands with Benja steps toward the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to rearrange his 3 x 5 index cards in his hands

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA
dialogues.text: There is a commotion in the rear of the audience.  BENJAMIN THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git your hand out of my pocket.  The bodyguards move toward the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, brothers. Don't get excited. Let's  cool it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up from the fourth row with 12-gauge sawed-off blasting.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Throws up his hands, grabs his chest and is knocked backw

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: People hit the floor, knock over chairs, stampede for the

dialogues.speaker: BACK OF AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: Wilbur Kinley ignites a smoke bomb.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RUN
dialogues.text: Thomas Hayer and Leon Davis stand up, run toward the stag their .45's and Luger into the fallen body of Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: She is on the floor covering her children.

dialogues.speaker: AISLE
dialogues.text: Hayer and Davis charge up the aisle toward the rear exit, the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: He stands in Hayer's way, Hayer fires, he turns, the bull the bodyguard gets off a shot which hits Hayer in the leg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stumbles momentarily, then limps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayer is running down the staircase when he is tripped, a through the air to the bottom of the landing. The crowd s the shit out of him, kicking him in the head, etc., they' tear him apart from limb to limb when a PATROLMAN enters He shoots gun into air and the crowd backs off and he tak Hayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Malcolm's bodyguards, BROTHER GENE, is over him, g mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. Brother Gene stops, Betty m hugs her dying husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody call an ambulance. Somebody call an  ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIRTY COPS walk in like it's a spring Sunday stroll in C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed him. They killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The person you know as Malcolm is no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSSIE DAVIS speaking behind the above:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here at this final hour, in this quiet place,  Harlem has come to bid farewell to one of its  brightest hopes, extinguished now and gone from  us forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 200C         DOLLY SHOT of the long line of people outsid waiting to see Malcolm's body, where it lies before buria

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Harlem is where he worked, and where he  struggled and fought. His home of homes, where  his heart was and where his people are. And it  is therefore most fitting that we meet once  again in Harlem to share these last moments  with him. For Harlem has ever been gracious to  those who loved her, have fought for her and  defended her honor even to death. It is not in  the memory of man that this beleaguered,  unfortunate but nonetheless proud community has  found a braver, more gallant young champion  than this Afro-American who lies before us  unconquered still. Many will ask what Harlem  finds to honor in this stormy, controversial  and bold young captain and we will smile and we  will answer and say unto them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordinary PEOPLE in ordinary pursuits of life, BLACK PEOPL struggling to stay afloat in a racist WHITE AMERICA that their best interests at hand -- 8 years of Reagan and now years of Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever talk to Brother Malcolm? Did you  have him smile at you? Did you ever listen to  him? Did he ever really do a mean thing? Was he  ever associated with violence or any public  disturbance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For if you did, you would know him and if you  knew him, you would know why we must honor him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm was our manhood, our living black  manhood. That was his meaning to his people and  in honoring him we honor the best in ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM BULLETIN BOARD
dialogues.text: A picture collage of Malcolm X. It reads P.S. 153 -- Harl Malcolm on his birthdate May 19, 1935.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we will know him then for what he was and  is. A PRINCE, A BLACK SHINING PRINCE who didn't  hesitate to die because he loved us so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS slowly to head of class where the teacher sta NELSON MANDELA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brother Malcolm said, "We declare our right  on this earth to be a man, to be a human being,  to be respected as a human being, in this  society, on this earth, in this day, which we  intend to bring into existence by any means  necessary."
